content:
This realy needs clarification. Best to have a worked example, I think.

I got very stuck in my clash, because there's multiple ways to understand "repeatedly calculating the absolute differences between adjacent numbers until only one number is left":

Example:
2 -4 9 9 -4
Method 1 (intended solution):
(2--4=>6) (-4-9=>13) (9-9=>0) (9--4=>13)
(6-13=>7) (13-0=>13) (0-13=>13)
(7-13=>6) (13-13=>0)
(6-0=>6)
6

Method 2 (2 at a time, many passes):
(2--4=>6) (9-9=>0) (-4=>-4)
(6-0=>6) (-4=>-4)
(6--4=>10)
10

Method 3 (reducing as you go, all in one pass):
(2--4=>6) (6-9=>3) (3-9=>6) (6--4=>10)
10

I tried Methods 2 and 3 first, which turned out to be the same thing in different masks.

It would be nice if the statement didn't leave it to the user to trial and error what the statement means through testing and instead was clear so you don't waste time.

It's a nice clash other than this ambiguity.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice!
Solved in 4 minutes:
l=[]
n = int(input())
for i in input().split():
    x = int(i)
    l.append(x)

while len(l) > 1:
    o=[]
    for i in range(len(l) - 1):
        o.append(abs(l[i] - l[i+1]))
    l=o

print(l[0])

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Completed in 7 minutes, after understanding I had to do a while loop (beginner level) :

n = int(input())
res = input().split()
while len(res) > 1:
    temp = []
    for i in range(len(res)-1):
        temp.append(abs(int(res[i])-int(res[i+1])))
    res = temp
print(res[0])

Input
* Line 2: Please add "separated by a space".

Output
* Please fix the two typos.

Thanks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is simple and interesting

Done!!!✅✅✅ 
Thanks for helping me improve this and other contributions.
